description: From Old French, from Latin coniectūra (“a guess”), from coniectus, perfect passive participle of cōniciō (“throw or cast together; guess”), from con- (“together”) + iaciō (“throw, hurl”); see jet. Compare adjective, eject, inject, project, reject, subject, object, trajectory.

entries.meaning: (formal) A statement or an idea which is unproven, but is thought to be true; a guess.
examples: I explained it, but it is pure conjecture whether he understood, or not.

entries.meaning: (formal) A supposition based upon incomplete evidence; a hypothesis.
examples: The physicist used his conjecture about subatomic particles to design an experiment.

entries.meaning: (mathematics, linguistics) A statement likely to be true based on available evidence, but which has not been formally proven.

verbs.description: conjecture (third-person singular simple present conjectures, present participle conjecturing, simple past and past participle conjectured)

entries.meaning: (formal, intransitive) To guess; to venture an unproven idea.
examples: I do not know if it is true; I am simply conjecturing here.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To infer on slight evidence; to guess at.
examples: Human reason can then, at the best, but conjecture what will be.
